paper_abstract: In 2004, Menezes and Smart left an open problem that is whether there exists a realistic scenario where message and key substitution (MKS) attacks can have damaging consequences. In this letter, we show that MKS attacks can have damaging consequences in practice, by pointing out that a verifiably encrypted signature (VES) scheme is not opaque if MKS attacks are possible.
paper_title: Message and Key Substitution Attacks on Verifiably Encrypted Signature Schemes
